I am content to suffer alone, while my sufferings shall endure: when I die, I am well satisfied that abhorrence and opprobrium should load my memory. Once my fancy was soothed with dreams of virtue, of fame, and of enjoyment. Once I falsely hoped to meet with beings, who, pardoning my outward form, would love me for the excellent qualities which I was capable of unfolding. I was nourished with high thoughts of honour and devotion. But now crime has degraded me beneath the meanest animal. No guilt, no mischief, no malignity, no misery, can be found comparable to mine. When I run over the frightful catalogue of my sins, I cannot believe that I am he whose thoughts were once filled with sublime and transcendent visions of the beauty and the majesty of goodness. But it is even so; the fallen angel becomes a malignant devil. Yet even that enemy of God and man had friends and associates in his desolation; I am alone.

"You, who call Frankenstein your friend, seem to have a knowledge of my crimes and his misfortunes. But in the detail which he gave you of them, he could not sum up the hours and months of misery which I endured, wasting in impotent passions. For while I destroyed his hopes, I did not satisfy my own desires. They were for ever ardent and craving; still I desired love and fellowship, and I was still spurned. Was there no injustice in this? Am I to be thought the only criminal, when all humankind sinned against me? Why do you not hate Felix, who drove his friend from his door with contumely? Why do you not execrate the rustic who sought to destroy the saviour of his child? Nay, these are virtuous and immaculate beings! I, the miserable and the abandoned, am an abortion, to be spurned at, and kicked, and trampled on. Even now my blood boils at the recollection of this injustice.

"But it is true that I am a wretch. I have murdered the lovely and the helpless; I have strangled the innocent as they slept, and grasped to death his throat who never injured me or any other living thing. I have devoted my creator, the select specimen of all that is worthy of love and admiration among men, to misery; I have pursued him even to that irremediable ruin. There he lies, white and cold in death. You hate me; but your abhorrence cannot equal that with which I regard myself. I look on the hands which executed the deed; I think on the heart in which the imagination of it was conceived, and long for the moment when these hands will meet my eyes, when that imagination will haunt my thoughts no more.

"Fear not that I shall be the instrument of future mischief. My work is nearly complete. Neither yours nor any man's death is needed to consummate the series of my being, and accomplish that which must be done; but it requires my own. Do not think that I shall be slow to perform this sacrifice. I shall quit your vessel on the ice-raft which brought me hither, and shall seek the most northern extremity of the globe. I shall collect my funeral pile, and consume to ashes this miserable frame, that its remains may afford no light to any curious and unhallowed wretch, who would create such another as I have been. I shall die. I shall no longer feel the agonies which now consume me, or be the prey of feelings unsatisfied, yet unquenched. He is dead who called me into being; and when I shall be no more, the very remembrance of us both will speedily vanish. I shall no longer see the sun or stars, or feel the winds play on my cheeks. Light, feeling, and sense will pass away; and in this condition must I find my happiness. Some years ago, when the images which this world affords first opened upon me, when I felt the cheering warmth of summer, and heard the rustling of the leaves and the warbling of the birds, and these were all to me, I should have wept to die; now it is my only consolation. Polluted by crimes, and torn by the bitterest remorse, where can I find rest but in death?

"Farewell! I leave you; and in you the last of humankind whom these eyes will ever behold. Farewell, Frankenstein! If thou wert yet alive, and yet cherished a desire of revenge against me, it would be better satiated in my life than in my destruction. But it was not so; thou didst seek my extinction, that I might not cause greater wretchedness; and if yet in some mode unknown to me thou hast not ceased to think and feel, thou wouldst not desire against me a vengeance greater than that which I feel. Blasted as thou wert, my agony was still superior to thine; for the bitter sting of remorse will not cease to rankle in my wounds until death shall close them for ever. But soon," he cried, with sad and solemn enthusiasm, "I shall die, and what I now feel be no longer felt. Soon these burning miseries will be extinct. I shall ascend my funeral pile triumphantly, and exult in the agony of the torturing flames. The light of that conflagration will fade away; my ashes will be swept into the sea by the winds. My spirit will sleep in peace; or if it thinks, it will not surely think thus. Farewell."

He sprang from the cabin-window, as he said this, upon the ice-raft which lay close to the vessel. He was soon borne away by the waves, and lost in darkness and distance.

I am yet dizzy with the remembrance of it. I hardly know whether I shall have the power to detail it; yet the recollection of the frightful events which have just passed, even now, makes my blood run cold, and my limbs tremble. I must collect myself, and attempt to relate them, for the sake of my own mind, if not for the benefit of those who may one day read these pages.

It was but a few hours ago that I was roused from a restless sleep by a loud and piercing shriek. I started from my bed, my heart beating with a violence that almost suffocated me. The moon shone brightly through the window, casting a pale and ghastly light upon the objects in the room. For a moment, I was bewildered, unable to distinguish whether I was awake or still under the influence of some dreadful dream. But the shriek was repeated, and I heard the sound of hasty footsteps along the corridor. I sprang from my bed, threw on my clothes with trembling hands, and rushed out of the room.

The house was in confusion. Servants were running to and fro, their faces pale with terror. I caught one by the arm and demanded the cause of the alarm. He could only point, speechless with horror, towards the chamber of Elizabeth. My heart sank within me. A thousand fears assailed me at once. I flew to the room, and, bursting open the door, beheld a sight which will haunt me to my dying day.

Elizabeth lay lifeless upon the bed, her face pale as marble, her eyes closed forever. The print of the murderer's grasp was on her neck. I threw myself beside her, calling her by name, but she was gone—gone forever. The agony of that moment cannot be described. I felt as if I had been suddenly deprived of all sensation, save that of insupportable despair. I tore my hair, and uttered wild exclamations of grief and rage. The servants gathered round me, but I heeded them not. My mind was wholly absorbed in the contemplation of the irreparable loss I had sustained.

At length, the first paroxysm of my grief having subsided, I began to reflect upon the cause of this dreadful event. The thought flashed across my mind that the fiend, my own accursed creation, had been the author of this misery. I remembered the threats he had uttered, the implacable hatred he had vowed against me, and the fatal warning he had given on the night of our marriage. "I shall be with you on your wedding-night." The words now rang in my ears with a dreadful distinctness. I had thought that I myself was to be the victim, but I was reserved for a far more bitter fate. My beloved Elizabeth, the pure and gentle being whom I had loved with all the ardour of my soul, had been sacrificed to my rash presumption.

I rushed from the room, determined to seek the murderer, and, if possible, to avenge the death of my wife. The night was dark and stormy; the wind howled around the house, and the rain fell in torrents. I wandered through the garden, calling upon the name of the fiend, and vowing eternal vengeance against him. But all was silent, save the voice of the tempest. I searched every spot where I thought it possible he might have concealed himself, but in vain. At length, exhausted by fatigue and agitation, I returned to the house, and threw myself upon a chair, overwhelmed by the weight of my misery.

The next morning, the magistrate and several officers of justice arrived to investigate the circumstances of the murder. I related to them all that had occurred, concealing nothing, and expressing my conviction that the murderer was not a human being, but a creature of my own formation. They listened to me with incredulity, and regarded me as a madman. I saw that it was useless to attempt to convince them, and relapsed into silence.

Days and nights passed in a state of the most dreadful despondency. I could not tear myself from the spot where my Elizabeth had expired. I wandered like a restless spectre through the house and grounds, haunted by the image of the fiend, and tormented by the recollection of my own folly and guilt. My health rapidly declined; I became emaciated and feeble, and my mind was a prey to the most gloomy and despairing thoughts.

At length, I resolved to quit the scene of my misery, and devote myself to the pursuit of the destroyer. I swore a solemn oath to pursue him to the ends of the earth, and to sacrifice my own life, if necessary, to the accomplishment of my revenge. With this determination, I set out upon my journey, armed with weapons, and provided with such necessaries as I might require in the prosecution of my design.

I travelled from place to place, guided by the faintest indications of the presence of the fiend. Sometimes I would hear of a being answering his description, who had been seen in some remote village or solitary dwelling. I would hasten to the spot, only to find that he had already departed, leaving behind him traces of his passage, and sometimes marks of his cruelty. Thus I was led on, from country to country, from city to city, always a little behind my enemy, but never able to overtake him.

During this period, my mind was a prey to the most violent emotions. I was alternately agitated by hope and fear, by rage and despair. The image of Elizabeth, murdered in the bloom of youth and beauty, was ever present to my imagination. I saw her in my dreams, pale and lifeless, her eyes closed in death, her lips cold and motionless. I heard her voice, calling to me for vengeance, and urging me to pursue the murderer without rest or mercy.

At length, after many months of fruitless search, I received intelligence that the fiend had been seen directing his course towards the north. I followed him with renewed ardour, determined to bring the pursuit to a close, or perish in the attempt. The journey was long and toilsome; I traversed vast deserts and frozen wastes, exposed to the most dreadful hardships and privations. But my resolution never faltered; the thought of my wrongs, and the desire of vengeance, sustained me through every trial.

At last, I reached the shores of the Arctic Ocean. Here, I found traces of the fiend, and learned that he had embarked in a sledge, drawn by dogs, upon the ice. I procured a similar conveyance, and set out in pursuit. The cold was intense, and the journey perilous in the extreme. The ice was broken and uneven, and I was often in danger of being swallowed up by the yawning chasms which opened before me. But I pressed on, heedless of danger, sustained by the hope of overtaking the object of my vengeance.

For many days, I pursued the track of the fiend across the frozen ocean. Sometimes, I would catch a glimpse of him in the distance, urging his dogs to greater speed. At other times, I would lose all trace of him, and be compelled to wander at random, in the hope of discovering some fresh indication of his route. My strength was nearly exhausted, and I was on the point of sinking under the weight of my sufferings, when I was discovered by a party of sailors, who had been sent out to explore the ice in search of a passage to the north.

They conveyed me on board their vessel, and administered to my wants with the greatest kindness and humanity. I related to them the story of my misfortunes, and implored them to assist me in the prosecution of my design. They listened to me with compassion, but were unable to comprehend the full extent of my misery. I remained with them for some time, my health gradually improving under their care, but my mind still harassed by the recollection of my wrongs, and the desire of vengeance.

Such is the history of the dreadful scene which has just taken place, and of the events which have followed it. I am now a broken and miserable man, bereft of all that made life dear to me, and sustained only by the hope of one day bringing the author of my misfortunes to justice. Whether I shall succeed in this object, or perish in the attempt, is known only to Him who rules the destinies of men. But, whatever may be the result, I shall never cease to pursue the fiend, and to devote every energy of my being to the accomplishment of my revenge.
